answer_text: Black and McDonalds’ role will be project management and project administration. We will also be the primary contact for Technical Support, and will assist Transnomis in project documentation, software testing, training, and device configuration. Black & McDonald will also provide crucial expertise to facilitate engagement and communication with hardware manufacturers, particularly to achieve a resolution in troubleshooting issues when there is uncertainty if the issue is a result of hardware manufacturer error, or with the traffic management control system.

Collectively B&M and Transnomis have many years of ITS and installation experience and are both recognized for successfully delivering similar type projects on time, and within budget. B&M and Transnomis have partnered on several successful high-profile projects, and two of those projects have recently won awards: Professional Engineers Ontario (PEO) York Chapter – Project of the Year (Small Project Category) 2023, and ITS Canada’s prestigious Smart Mobility Project of the Year Award 2022.

In this phase we will plan out how the B&M / Transnomis Team will execute the TMaCS project in collaboration with HHB. We expect to carry out this planning phase remotely, with a weekly virtual meeting with the HHB Team. To ensure efficient completion of this phase, we propose the following weekly rhythm for all subtasks in this phase: Monday – Wednesday – B&M Team creates the draft plan; Thursday Zoom/Teams meeting with HHB – B&M Team presents the draft plan, and seeks HHB feedback and comments; Friday – B&M Team submits the draft plan to HHB for final review and approval.

HHB will provision the necessary virtual machines (VMs) and remote access for the B&M / Transnomis Team for this project. Deliverable (HHB): Credentials and VPN instructions regarding remote access to VMs.
The project team has previously delivered two high profile projects featuring the Smartmicro Radar technology.

ITS Central has a unique and innovative real time animated visualization of vehicles, bikes, and peds, allowing operators to intuitively see speeds, vehicle size, locations, headway, and incidents at a glance.
Our project team’s software is customizable and modular, and ready for future expansion.

Black & McDonald will take responsibility for the following duties: Project management and coordination, Project updates and scheduling, Minutes of meetings, Coordination/Documentation of requests, communications, questions, and answers, Leading the gathering of requirements, Assist Transnomis in software testing, device configuration, and training, Coordinate with hardware manufacturers if required, Coordinate the on-site calibration of Smartmicro Sensors (required for integration of Smartmicro Sensors in ITS Central), Provide 24/7 product support throughout the maintenance period and assist in troubleshooting (particularly in determining whether or not an issue is hardware- or software-related).

Peter has almost a decade of experience managing and facilitating the deployment of ITS technologies across Canada. As an International Municipal Signal Association (IMSA) certified technician and an experienced account manager, Peter understands the process of deploying complex hardware and software platforms for traffic and transportation applications.

Afra has over 17 years of experience in the ITS field as a PMP and Electronics Engineer. Afra has been involved with several P3 and major projects incorporating new ITS technologies and systems. This includes several years of experience on projects with the City of Toronto working on VMS replacement, Traffic Signal Control Systems, ATMS, toll systems, Intersection management, Traffic Counting Station, Speed Enforcement, and Adaptive systems.

Yeatland was also a member of the Project Steering Committee for Transportation Association of Canada’s Guidelines for the Planning, Design, Operation and Evaluation of Reversible Lane Systems, and worked extensively with the lead author on the research, review, and content of this important document.

Current State Evaluation is the sub-phase where the B&M / Transnomis Team performs an in-depth review of all existing conditions and information from HHB that are necessary for the successful implementation of the project. This phase will initially be conducted as a 'fact-finding mission' by B&M/Transnomis Team attending the HHB facility in person right after Project Kickoff.

We will perform an assessment on all hardware in-scope to be integrated with TMaCS. This includes gathering of the following information (without limitation): Network architecture diagram(s), Make/model of devices (confirmation of what is in the RFP), IP address, Port number, Network protocol (e.g., TCP or UDP), Credentials specific to the devices (e.g., community strings), Communication protocol used (e.g., NTCIP, Modbus, etc.), Documentations from device manufacturers (e.g., user manual, protocol specifications, etc.).

We will perform an assessment on the operational needs that are beyond the existing system, or not captured on Day 4. This includes gathering of the following information (without limitation): Q&A and confirmation of understanding of the existing lane reversal operation, Further and in-depth discussions on what the existing is doing well and what can be improved in TMaCS to improve on the operations, Other significant operational requirements that should be captured in the TMaCS design, Report and dashboard needs in TMaCS.

Highway Engineering scope includes Roadside Safety Design in accordance with MTO’s Roadside Design Manual (May 2020) considering traffic on both Garden City Skyway as well as adjacent sideroads for all proposed roadside installations (new VMS signs, WDE towers) and adjacent existing hazards (e.g. light standards).
We will identify risks that may be involved in the implementation and upgrade and provide mitigation strategies. We will revise the implementation and upgrade plan if needed.

Our developers will implement the TMaCS lane control user interface and control logic based on the mock-ups developed in the previous subtask. System Demos will be provided to HHB in project meetings to ensure the implementation meets the expectations of HHB. A formal System Demo is scheduled after the completion of primary development. This System Demo includes basic training, and a walk through of the features.

Following the completion of the field and laboratory analytical program, Englobe will evaluate the geotechnical conditions encountered at the discrete borehole locations and subsequently prepare a draft geotechnical report in accordance with the RFP. The geotechnical report will provide factual results of the investigation and foundation design and construction recommendations. The report will include drawings that show the overall Site and the position of the specific borehole locations investigated as part of the Geotechnical Investigation. The drawings will be made to an approximate scale of sufficient accuracy to identify the various site features and investigation locations during future site visits. In addition, borehole stratigraphic logs will be provided detailing the findings of the drilling activities. Upon receiving comments from the Client, Englobe will finalize an electronic version of the report.

Our installation and configuration specialist will install and configure the PostgreSQL database (and its required extensions TimescaleDB and PostGIS) as well as the ITS Central web application and its integration gateway modules into the production VMs. Deliverable: ITS Central database and software installed and configured in Production VMs.

Our hardware configuration specialist will configure hardware devices in ITS Central (e.g., IP addresses, port numbers, etc.). Communication to the devices will be confirmed. Deliverable: Hardware devices configured in ITS Central.
We will configure data reports and dashboards based on the needs of HHB as assessed in the current state evaluation task. Deliverable: Pre-configured reports and dashboards in ITS Central.

Transnomis ITS Central software always supports the latest operating system and browser environments. If the operating system is coming to end-of-life, and an in-place OS upgrade is not feasible or deemed too risky, Transnomis will work with HHB on a migration plan to move the existing installation into the new server with the new OS. The plan will include scheduling, specific steps for the migration, go live plan on the new system and the decommissioning of the old system. This is included in the ongoing support and will not require a change order.

Our QA specialist will create a system integration test plan that focuses on testing ITS Central’s monitoring and control of hardware devices: VMS, gantry lane control signs, barrier gates and CCTV. The SIT plan will exercise all functions of these hardware. Where the tests require the control live traffic devices, we will coordinate with HHB on the necessary warnings and traffic control needed (e.g., testing the control of the gates). Deliverable: SIT Plan.

Our QA specialist will create a test plan that exercises the entire workflow of the lane control logic and GUI, including the routine scenarios (e.g., the daily third lane reversals) and the less frequent scenarios (e.g., one-way traffic only, incident blocking one lane on bridge). Deliverable: Lane Control Test Plan.

Our automation QA specialist will create the automation testing script to execute the lane control test plan. The automation test script will be integrated as part of the continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) process. All future changes to ITS Central will be tested against this test script and we can be assured that future enhancements and bug fixes will not break this new functionality. Note that we already have automation QA test script for all other existing ITS Central functions. Deliverable: Automation QA Implemented for Lane Control functionalities as part of the CI/CD process.

Our documentation/training specialist will create the user and admin manuals. It will be based on our existing ITS Central user/admin manuals, customized to HHB’s context and with the lane control functionality added. Deliverable: User and admin manuals.

Our documentation/training specialist will create a training plan that includes step-by-step guides and fully hands-on exercises. Training will be provided in person to HHB staff during the weeks 23-24 of the project. Deliverable: Training plan and in-person training.

A date and time will be arranged with HHB to go-live with the new TMaCS. Transnomis staff will be available on-site to address any questions and provide additional support to the operations staff. All issues will be addressed in an expedited and urgent fashion. Deliverable: a successful go-live of TMaCS with on-site in person support from Transnomis.

We will arrange meetings with the relevant HHB staff to review the processes that will utilize the TMaCS to track and coordinate incidents and services, including: Incident response, Security checks, Visual hardware inspection, Special events, Maintenance management. In the meetings, we will discuss how ITS Central can be configured and used in each of these contexts for HHB, as well as how it has been used in other jurisdictions dealing with similar issues. Deliverable: Incident and service management process review meetings and minutes.

We will arrange a workshop meeting with HHB to discuss and specify how weather station data (road conditions, temperature, etc.) will be used to create automated messages for the VMS, as well as alerts for the operators. Deliverable: Control logic workshop and minutes.

In preparation for go live with this phase, we will: Update the user and admin manuals as needed, Provide user training, Reports and dashboard configuration, Create a go-live planning document that minimizes and mitigate risks involved. We anticipate the go-live with this phase will be far more straightforward than Phase 1.0. Deliverable: Phase 1.2 go live, with updated documentation and training.

Transnomis is performing a technology stack upgrade such that by year 2024, ITS Central can be installed on either Windows or Linux OS. Since ITS Central relies on only off-the-shelf and open-source software (Linux and PostgreSQL databases), there are no third-party licenses required (e.g., database licenses).

Transnomis has been building a comprehensive Intelligent Transportation System (ITS) called ITS Central to provide specialized ATMS control for ITS since 2007. Transnomis’ packaged service offerings include: ITS Central – a map-centric, modular Advanced Traffic Management System (ATMS) central software, VMS Central – a cloud-hosted solution available to work zone traffic safety companies, allowing them to configure and create their own 'Smart Work Zones.'

The proposed TMaCS system will use a customized deployment of ITS Central, Transnomis’s flagship ATMS software. It has been implemented by many major transportation agencies including: Ontario Ministry of Transportation (MTO), City of Toronto, City of Edmonton, City of Loveland, Region of Waterloo, Region of Durham, Region of York, BC Ferries.

ITS Central seamlessly integrates internal systems, field traffic control devices, traffic data, and external data sources into a map-centric intelligent traffic management system. The solution scales to any organization’s size and needs, ranging from a small standalone application up to a large-scale advanced traffic management solution.

For the TMaCS project, Transnomis will integrate the HHB devices per the RFP, and configure ITS Central to allow for integration of data and device control. During the engagement sessions, input will be taken from HHB to ensure that the user interface and dashboards reflect the needs of HHB’s existing processes, and to enhance those processes with the modern features of ITS Central’s capabilities.

Transnomis believes their breadth and depth of experience in providing modern integrated traffic solutions to government entities of all sizes make them uniquely qualified for this project. Some of our clients include City of Toronto, Ontario Ministry of Transportation, City of Edmonton, City of Loveland (Colorado), Durham Region, Government of Northwest Territories, and British Columbia Ferries.

The system will have the ability to track and report what data changes were made, when they were made, and by which end user. All user accounts maintain detailed records of all activity taken, including logging in/out, downloading files, editing entities, and so on. An audit list showing date/time, IP, action taken, and account names is available, as is the ability to check an individual account and audit only their actions. Individual entities also support auditing, which shows all actions taken by all accounts that relate to that entity. These audits can be accessed by administrator accounts with the correct permissions, allowing for a high level of transparency and trackability within the system. In the TMaCS project, every step taken during lane reversals will be fully logged and auditable.

Our clients always have full ownership and control of the data stored in our software. Transnomis and the B&M team do not claim ownership or make use of any client data outside of the project without client consent. ITS Central supports clients’ own unique data governance models. We understand that different organizations have their own unique processes, organization charts, and data collection systems. We have built ITS Central in such a way that can accommodate a wide variety of data governance models that work for organizations as large as the City of Toronto, Ontario Ministry of Transportation, and the City of Edmonton, to small towns and townships in Ontario such as the Township of Lanark Highlands.

The system should have configuration capabilities for reporting to meet ongoing Business needs. The system should have the ability to report on all system data through a reporting engine. The system should have the following pre-built reports; History reports, dates / times / messaging, how many signs, how many scheduled / unscheduled. Communication status reports for all devices. Reports are a highly configurable module in ITSC. Any number of standard reports can be easily created and saved according to desired specifications. These reports can contain a mixture of tabular and graph data (depending on the data used and the report options chosen) and will automatically refresh with new data every time a user opens them.

B&M believes that excellence in occupational health, safety & environment is a philosophy inherent to how we do business in all aspects of our operations. We believe that the measures we take will help drive B&M closer to our vision of a workplace where “Nobody Gets Hurt Today or Tomorrow”. Our management team is committed to putting our people first in meeting our customer’s challenges in the most critical environments. B&M believes the most effective way to avoid any potential risks to people and the environment and to meet our HSE commitment is through a competent, committed workforce and practices designed to ensure the resultant risk is effectively managed proactively. We accomplish this by effective implementation of our Hazard Identification Elimination Risk Assessment & Control (HIERAC) processes and B&M HSE Manual.

The system will provide expandability to include future equipment (physical assets) and services (e.g., data ingestion). ITSC is an extremely adaptable system with support for the ingestion of large amounts of data/new devices.

Ensuring that ITS Central remains performant at all times is one of our highest priorities. A number of performance-improving techniques are used throughout the platform, including: Database query tuning, Code review for performance optimization, Database table index, In-memory caching, Minification, Image sprites.

The Vendor shall provide custom reports for the purposes of monitoring performance of the System, which could include any or all event and traffic data gathered by the Solution. The Vendor shall collaborate with the Owner to determine the configuration, processing, and default content of the custom reports. A maximum of 10 reports will be requested.

The system will provide an integrated flexible solution for incident and service management and associated reporting. Service management in this context include non-incidents, e.g., an entry for daily security check rounds, or visual inspection of VMS signs, or logging a special event that requires a special lane reversal. All entries require auditability and controls. Incidents can be logged in the new TMaCS via ITSC’s powerful Issues module. New issues can be created using a template with predefined data fields, streamlining the process of adding common or recurring issues into the system. This functionality also lends itself well to creating standardized logs, such as those needed for daily security checks or noting that a visual inspection of the VMS signs was performed. These logs can be automatically sent to chosen emails for record-keeping purposes (in addition to the system’s built-in auditing and issue review features).

After the integration is complete, ITS Central will manage and operate all existing HHB Variable message signs. This will include posting of messages, scheduled messages, and automated messages. If supported by the hardware’s available API, this will also include monitoring of VMS maintenance issues such as pixel failure. Both manual and automated messages always include a priority ranking. This simplifies the task of the Operator, such that the Operator does not need to decide which message should be posted. The Operator only needs to decide if a message needs to be posted, and what the priority protocol is for that message.

The planned User Interface for this 3-lane reversible system will include safeguards and operational functions that include, but are not limited to: User Authorization (or as following HHB protocols) prior to reversal, User Confirmation before beginning sequence, Semi-automated Camera verification (User confirmation that lane is clear), Posting warnings on VMS boards (if part of existing HHB procedures), Flashing Red X sequence for minimum Transition Time (per TAC standards), Solid Red X in two directions for minimum Clearance Time, Alert the Operator if Smartmicro detects that the reversing lane is not yet clear, Operator provides final confirmation that the system is ready for counterflow operation, Post Green Arrow for the reversed lane and change gate state to allow counterflow traffic.

Integration of Smartmicro sensor technologies to build out traffic queue lengths and to alert the TMaCS of heavy traffic conditions and send an associate alert / post message to the VMS sign(s). As part of the Smartmicro radar sensor integration, these sensors will be integrated into ITS Central with semi automation. The project team will work with HHB to establish the logic, thresholds, and scenario messaging associated with events detected by these sensors.

Our Product Roadmap is led by our senior management, and includes short term, medium term, and long-term product strategic releases, driven by our customer needs and feedback. Over the history of ITS Central’s development, Transnomis has incorporated numerous new features, device integrations, and product enhancements. Product enhancements and roadmaps are driven by customer needs and feedback. We engage our customers through surveys, engagement workshops, training workshops, and allowing for direct suggestions and requests.

Transnomis Solutions strives to produce the highest quality software and services to customers through continuous development of our quality management system as well as its consistent implementation. Customers can expect Transnomis Solutions software to meet or exceed their requirements and expectations. We establish Quality Control Processes (QCP) to achieve our quality objectives, namely: Consistently meeting or exceeding customer requirements, Zero/Minimal software support issues, Detailed and accurate documentation.

Transnomis software is designed to be reliable and responsive. Should any issue be detected in the software, the software itself will automatically notify Transnomis staff. All Transnomis software modules are covered by automated software issue logging and alerts. Should a module fail and/or crash, our software will automatically log it as an issue into the database and will send out a notification email to Transnomis Solutions staff.

In the event of abnormal program shutdown or service failure, support staff will work with HHB IT Staff to remotely resolve the issue by restarting the server, restarting the software, restoring the backup database, and/or restarting the appropriate software module as appropriate. Emergency updates may involve expedited software changes and deployment.

Software change requests should provide the desired outcome of the change request or feature, as well as the contact information for the submitter, and priority level of the request. For software requests which are within the scope of the project, or if a change order is warranted, the following process will be followed: 1. Transnomis Solutions will generate a tracking ticket for the request. 2. The issue will be reviewed, and a software developer will be assigned to handle the ticket. 3. A software fix will be developed and tested in the QA development environment. 4. A software fix will be pushed to the servers outside of primary operational hours at a time agreed upon with the HHB. 5. The software changes will be documented within the tracking ticket.

A formal maintenance plan will be provided that describes the ongoing support maintenance. Some of this plan will be customized based on the specifics of the detailed design. Generally, the maintenance model will include the following elements: Preventative Maintenance, Emergency support / General support.

Together we have delivered several projects including: Ontario Ministry of Transportation Queue and Stopped Vehicle Advisory System (QSVAS): This project uses 40 Smartmicro radar sensors to detect traffic issues and stopped vehicles along the 8km approach to the border crossing in Niagara Region. After detecting issues, the system automatically posts contextually appropriate messages to one of four VMS.

Our proposed software has a unique feature that allows for user customizable dashboards, to reflect alerts, reports, graphs, cameras, and more. Users can configure multiple dashboards and display them on multiple monitors. Different users can adapt their dashboards to reflect different KPIs or areas of specialization.

The SLA will typically involve the following elements: Performance Measures: This proposal and costing are based on 99.9% Uptime outside of scheduled and routine maintenance and server / failover server issues within the scope of HHB’s IT team. Response Times; maximum 1 hour for High Priority Emergency calls, 6 hours for Medium Priority requests, and 24 hours for Low Priority requests.

Project kickoff is arguably the most important part of the project as much of the foundation of the project success is laid during this initiation phase of the project. We believe a strong connection between project team members is vital to the success of the project. As such, we propose that the Project Kickoff will be held in person at HHB’s facility.

We will perform an assessment on the existing lane control system. This includes gathering of the following information (without limitation): Attend both the morning and afternoon third-lane reversals, paying specific attention to how the existing software is operating, recording the process and screen if permitted. Observe and receive feedback from HHB on what the existing system is doing well. Observe and receive feedback from HHB on what can be improved upon in TMaCS.

We will develop a detailed plan of how the TMaCS will be implemented – from software development, QA/QC, Training and Go-Live – at a high level. The implementation plan may be a revision of the plan presented in this proposal based on new information obtained in Project Kickoff and Phase 1.0.1. The overarching objective of this plan is to minimize disruption to bridge operation.

Based on understanding from the current state evaluation, we will develop a data governance plan, which will include items such as: Users and user groups that should be configured in the system, Permissions of each user groups in the system: who can be permitted to do what, Division of data into separate data layers, Meta data and fields that are needed, A review of existing ITS Central auditing.

Our installation and configuration specialist will install and configure the PostgreSQL database (and its required extensions TimescaleDB and PostGIS) as well as the ITS Central web application and its integration gateway modules into the staging VMs. Deliverable: ITS Central database and software installed and configured in Staging VMs.
In this phase we will carry out the QA/QC tasks necessary to ensure the system performs as specified with no issues (e.g., crashes, error messages, or performance issues).

Since some tests will involve live traffic devices, B&M / Transnomis Team proposes to perform the test execution in person at HHB facilities. The test execution will be coordinated with HHB operations staff to minimize impact to the HHB operations and live traffic. Tests will be witnessed by HHB, and test results will be documented and provided to HHB. Tests will include platform testing and failover testing. Deliverable: Test executed and test results documentation.

In preparation for go live with this phase, we will: Update the user and admin manuals as needed, Provide user training, Reports and dashboard configuration, Create a go-live planning document that minimizes and mitigate risks involved. We anticipate the go-live with this phase will be far more straightforward and less risk than Phase 1.0. Deliverable: Phase 1.1 go live, with updated documentation and training.

HHB will be required to handle the following duties: Providing documentation on existing systems, devices, and processes, Provision virtual machines (VMs) for the staging and production instances, Provide secure remote network access for system support and maintenance, Review and provide feedback/answers to inquiries, Assisting Black & McDonald / Transnomis Team as required for VM setup, network access, and software installation, Providing access to the traffic control centre and lane closures, as required for testing.

Provide security framework/compliance alignment, if applicable. Transnomis is currently pursuing the Cyber Secure Canada security certification and expects to achieve certification by Q2 of 2024. Transnomis has policies that apply to all software and hardware at the company and that govern the procedures and security measures that must be followed for any manually updated, or non-updated, software and hardware.

Transnomis has built the software from the ground up with a focus on reliability — the uptime goal for all systems we provide is 99.99% excluding routinely scheduled server maintenance. ITS Central is known to operate continuously for months and years without issue.

The system will have the adaptability for future changes to TMaCS processes, allowing for expandability in the form of added software features. ITS Central is built in a modular manner. This allows for customization for clients, and new features can be adapted or created for HHB as TMaCS evolves its systems and processes.

Black & McDonald and Transnomis are proud of the ITS Central platform and its record of usability and satisfied operators. We have built this platform to be stable, user-friendly, and responsive. Great care is taken to ensure that users are satisfied with the product. More importantly, the project leads from Transnomis are former users of operation centre software and will help guide the design process to ensure that the product is built with the user in mind. During the Current State Evaluation project phase, user requirements will be recorded and documented. These user requirements may go beyond the Proposal’s objective requirements, and there will be flexibility to include desired features beyond that of the existing system. Operators may have insight into the existing system, and provide requests such as dark mode dashboards, additional safeguards/verifications, or other features that were not specified in the original RFP. These HHB and HHB operator insights and suggestions will be recorded and tempered against the existing system framework, technical constraints, and practicality, then used as an input during the Implementation phase. Every effort will be used to ensure the system maintains its reputation as being user friendly and easy to learn. The insights and suggestions from that engagement will be used as the basis for later user evaluation. Mock-ups will be shared with HHB and will include 'what we heard' from the engagement session. HHB will be asked to review and ensure that the mock-ups and the 'what we heard' suggestions and insights are reflective of the user’s needs. As the system is being built and implemented, informal demos will be performed, particularly when the Software Project Manager is looking for further input on specific features. A formal System Demo is scheduled after the completion of primary development. This System Demo includes basic training, and a walk through of the features. HHB will be given access to use and test the system and provide feedback. A series of questions will be provided to HHB to survey their opinions on the system, guided by the original input from the engagement and Detailed Design. We have allocated one week for HHB to use the system, ask questions, and provide feedback. The feedback from this System Demo period will be used to guide final changes and system tweaks to ensure the system meets the needs of HHB. During the Go-Live periods, Transnomis staff will be on-hand to observe how HHB operations staff use TMaCS, and take note on any opportunity for improvements. Transnomis staff can directly address any questions and issues immediately. Urgently required changes will be made in an expedited fashion. Most importantly, the project team is highly experienced and have direct hands-on operational experience in traffic management centres and with lane reversal systems, as well as in building software for users.

At Transnomis Solutions, the technical team practices Continuous Integration (CI). Developers merge their code into a shared repository (GitLab) several times a day and the code in each merge is tested using automated testing. The CI process is supported by the use of popular tools like Jenkins, VS Test, Selenium, Nunit and Zalenium.

Transnomis has built the software from the ground up with a focus on reliability. We understand that HHB is using this system for safety critical processes and have a reputation of safe and reliable service to its customers. The uptime goal for all systems we provide is 99.9%. This primary KPI is monitored via a third-party Uptime monitoring service.

Our integrated team for design/build services of Intelligent Transportation Systems address the unique needs of Municipal Governments and the Ministry of Transportation. Purposeful cooperation, teamwork, alignment of common goals, full transparency and information sharing of risk and rewards ensures mutual success.

Black & McDonald Limited manages and takes responsibility for all aspects of projects and maintenance agreements while ensuring a continuity of processes deliverables such as health, safety, environmental compliance, quality assurance, continuous improvement and economies of scale.

Working on the Skyway presents many risks to field crew and public safety. The Skyway is significantly elevated, experiences extreme weather and does not offer any shoulders on either side. It is our top priority to ensure the safety of all project team members and the travelling public when working on this contract. All field crew members will have mandatory safety training refresher courses delivered. No crew member will be permitted to work on the contract without providing proof of training. Daily tailboard safety meetings will be conducted at the yard prior to arrival on-site. Daily meetings will review the work to be conducted, the traffic control plan staging, safety protocols and coordination with vendors or technical support.
The Solution shall raise alerts for adverse weather conditions detected within configurable time interval from first identification.

LEA is committed to the principle that our success is measured in terms of our client's satisfaction and the realization of their social, economic, and environmental objectives. We treat your business as our own by partnering with you on all levels. We look for ways to create added value, to go above and beyond to deliver results that exceed expectations rather than just meet them.

Globe Network Integrators Inc. will provide a support role during the design phase of this project. Although they are not the designers, they will provide input to the design process based on their experience in other MTO projects. Globe will also develop the Material Selection Submission for the communication network components proposed for use in the project.

Transnomis’ ITS Central also powers the Transnomis Municipal511 web service. Municipal511 serves 45% of Ontario municipalities directly, and numerous public and private stakeholders indirectly through the Ontario Good Roads Association (OGRA) Municipal Alliance for Connected and Autonomous Vehicles in Ontario (MACAVO) initiative.

Transnomis has had 14 years of experience building user friendly software control systems for road information management and ITS device communications with its flagship central system software, ITS Central.

The GCSS System must be able to accurately report on the position of stopped or stalled slow queues of vehicles in order to protect exposed drivers stopped in live lanes. A similar situation occurs when vehicle queues are present on the Skyway. Drivers must be warned of as to the location and distance to vehicle queues present issues on the Skyway, in order to prepare to slow down upon entry.

The Solution shall automatically activate the Solution-dedicated VMS in response with appropriate messages based on Owner-prescribed message text, graphics and combined text-graphics templates depending on the condition detected and attributes of the detection location.
The Solution shall provide the ability to manually override system generated and posted message on VMS.

Leveraging our expertise across traffic engineering, utilities, energy management, and mechanical and electrical construction, B&M provides turnkey ITS infrastructure solutions for Municipal, regional and provincial clients.

This project will involve the design, construction, operation and maintenance of a new Safety Advisor System to manage all Eastbound & Westbound lanes of traffic across the expanse of the Skyway. The project will include three phases: System Design, Construction/System and Proof-Of-Performance Testing. Following successful completion of the SIT, System Acceptance Testing for the duration of 8 months will occur. B&M will then be responsible for the operation and maintenance for a duration of 48 months following successful System Acceptance Testing.

B&M understands the detection solution must be capable of identifying isolated stopped vehicles and aggregated queued vehicles on a lane-by-lane basis; as well as dynamic, continuous, and uninterrupted detection with no blind spots.

B&M places the utmost importance on the completion of projects on-schedule and on budget. To this end, B&M develops detailed Critical Path Method schedule utilizing latest Microsoft Project. It allows the schedule to be mutually established and easily updated, thus encompassing all of the interrelated requirements, milestones, and final completion dates involved in the completion of the project delivered through an integrated team approach. B&M assigns a dedicated Project Scheduler for every project who is primarily responsible for supporting the Project Manager in scheduling activities including-creating baseline schedules, updating schedules on a weekly or bimonthly basis to incorporate change orders, identifying and monitoring the Critical Path and escalating any anticipated delays to the Project Manager.

The Solution shall be capable of automatically activating VMS to display messages according to the following rules and shall be configurable to adapt to modifications of these rules: Messages shall indicate actual lane configuration and affected lanes at queue end or isolated stopped vehicle location, as applicable, at any point within the System Limits, to address specific conditions and correlated messages. Messages shall distinguish between slow and stopped traffic at the queue end, based on user-configurable system parameters. Messages shall indicate approximate distance to downstream queue end or isolated stopped vehicle, as applicable, based on ranges defined as user-configurable system parameters. The Vendor shall work in collaboration with the Owner to determine any modifications required to the above rules.

B&M will maintain and provide operational support for the GCSS System over a four-year term. Upon completion of the operational support and maintenance period, B&M will decommission the GCSS System upon confirmation from the MTO.

Triple Redundancy Server & Comms: Primary server with a secondary server (hot standby) and tertiary server (cold standby), complete with streaming replication, and wireless backup communications to all three servers. This provides high availability of the system, and onsite backups.

Our Project Team’s proposal and fees includes the following innovative approaches, above the provided specifications: A radar test site will be installed on the project site, to facilitate sensor integration, validate data, and allow for early evaluation of site-specific traffic sensor data.

The project team will install a Smartmicro Radar test site on the Garden City Skyway. The test site will provide sensor data to Transnomis Solutions such that any issues related to data interpretation will be detected and rectified early in the contract. The proposed sensor for the test site will include video and radar integration. This will allow for remote data validation. Any issues related to sensor position, height or alignment will be detected early, providing the team with the opportunity to rectify the test site before installing other sensors. Due to the safety concerns associated with working on the Skyway, it is important that sensor installations are completed efficiently and in a timely manner. The test site will allow future sensor installations to be completed with reliability such that field crews will not need to return to make adjustments. Regular system testing will allow the team to discover and solve previously unknown issues, provide Transnomis a head start on software development and refine the project teams testing procedure for the remaining sensors. A sensor test site will be installed early into the contract for system testing and discovery. We believe this approach helped lead to the success of the QSVAS project.

Our GCSS System solution will incorporate the following high availability features designed specifically for the QSVAS for 24/7 non-stop operation: Triple server setup in 3 separate cabinets: Primary server; Secondary server setup with streaming replication with the primary server and automatic failover should the primary server fails; and Third server setup with streaming replication with the primary server as cold standby server ready to take over as 'Secondary Server' should one of the above servers fails.

A second opportunity for an innovative approach is to assign fibers 21 to 24 continuously through the network, so that the GCSS and QSVAS segments can be interconnected. This would allow safety messages and warnings to be shared between both systems, increasing its utility for the MTO. It would also reduce the risk of server downtime, as the servers could be shared between both systems. Finally, this approach would allow the MTO Operators to access both systems through one dashboard.

Transnomis’ ITS Central with custom modules and configurations is proposed to be the GCSS Central Software. Transnomis’ ITS Central is a versatile map-centric event management system capable of integrating traffic sensors, CCTV, VMS, as well as a large number of internal data sources and external open data sources. It runs on any off-the-shelf Windows Server - hardware or virtual machine. The web front end uses Internet Information Services (IIS) with Model-View-Controller (MVC) technologies where data is stored in a high performance, open-source relational database PostgreSQL.
In order to stay updated on the latest ITS technology, industry standards and occupational health and safety, Black & McDonald schedules regular training session for man power and field personnel.

With a Mean Time Between Failure (MBTF) of 44.5 years, this unit is intended to be deployed and left in place with minimal maintenance. It also has an operating temperature range of -20°C to +60°C, which exceeds the requirements for Ethernet Switches in MTO Specification 683S25.

The Smartmicro UMRR-12 Type 48 radar is the proposed traffic sensor solution to monitor and report isolated stopped vehicles or vehicle queues. The Type 48 radar is a 24 GHz, forward firing radar sensor used for multi-lane, multi-object tracking traffic management applications. The Type 48 sensor features innovative 4D – Ultra High Definition (UHD) object tracking technology.
Type 48 radar provides presence detection accuracy of greater than 95 percent. Detect stopped vehicles within a maximum of five seconds of their occurrence on the roadway.

The sensor operates in a wide temperature interval between -40 to +74 degrees Celsius, suitable for the Canadian climate. The sensor is housed within an IP 67 rated enclosure, immune to the ingress of water or dust infiltration.

Smartmicro sensors are deployed globally, operating in the world's harshest climates. From the deserts of Dubai to Northern Russia, Smartmicro sensors detect reliability 24/7. Radar is the most robust sensing technology and is not affected by dirt, smog, sunlight, wind, rain or snow.

The proposed environmental sampling program will be conducted in general accordance with MECP sampling protocols, as described in the MECP document “Guide for Completing Phase Two ESAs under O. Reg. 153/04,” dated June 2011 and in the MECP document “Protocol for Analytical Methods Used in the Assessment of Properties under Part XV.1 of the Environmental Protection Act,” dated March 9, 2004, amended as of July 1, 2011 (Analytical Protocol). The RFP document does not specify any analytical testing to be performed on the collected soil samples. However, the following testing is proposed to support the disposal of the excess spoil material generated from drilling activities and in anticipation of the design and construction requirements for the VMS and CCTV concrete pole foundation elements: Corrosivity package test on three (3) selected soil samples (one per borehole); and One composite soil sample to be submitted for toxicity characteristic leaching procedure (TCLP) analysis.

The Solution shall perform a persistence check to confirm a “stable event”, so as not to have the VMS display change messages rapidly. The Solution shall implement a minimum time between changing of messages. ITS Central incorporates two types of persistence checks. The first persistence check is at the issue creation level – an issue is not generated unless it has been stable for longer than the configured time. The second persistence check is at the VMS level – messages posted automatically to the VMS will persist for the minimum configured time – to prevent messages from changing rapidly.

The Solution shall provide the ability to reject a detected alert, which would automatically remove the messages posted or changes in state on applicable VMS. When an issue has been created in ITS Central for QSVAS, it will automatically activate the required VMS signs. If a user determines that the detected issue is a false alarm, they may change the issue status by clicking the Declare False Alarm option. This will update the status of the issue to “False Alarm”, which will automatically remove any related posted messages.

The Solution shall provide the ability to manually override system generated and posted messages on VMS. In ITS Central, VMS messaging may be manually overridden and messages may be replaced in the following ways on a sign-by-sign basis: A VMS may be manually “blanked.” A manual message may be posted immediately to a particular sign. This option is best for posting urgent messages (e.g., border closures, AMBER alerts) as it involves the fewest steps. Note that this will also disable automated messaging for that sign.

The Solution shall post the message with highest priority rating on the dedicated VMS and retain all other messages with lower priorities in message queue. If two messages assigned to the same VMS have an equal priority rating, the message for the closest event downstream of the VMS shall be posted on the VMS. ITS Central supports five (5) levels of scheduling priorities – Very Low, Low, Medium, High and Very High, where at any given moment, the applicable message, based on the specified time / day recurrence, that has the highest priority will be posted to the VMS.

ITS Central (ITSC) uses a map-based interface that is supported across all modern browsers. User Acceptance Testing (UAT), or application testing, is the final stage of any software development or change request lifecycle before go-live. All issues observed (if any) shall be documented, discussed and approved for resolution before final system acceptance and Go Live.

The sensors will read the MAC addresses of detected devices (Bluetooth & Wi-Fi) as they pass through the sensor’s detection radius (minimum 100m). Device MAC addresses are hashed and encrypted and sent to ITS Central software instance via local LTE modem connection. ITS Central receives hashed MAC addresses continuously from all sensors and processes the data into matches in order to calculate link travel time data.

These devices are integrated into a non-metallic enclosure to provide the integrated all-in-one solution The Ministry has requested. They will utilize external weatherproof omni directional antennas for long range and robust detection for highway environments. Each transceiver will have a dedicated antenna (1 for Bluetooth, 1 for Wi-Fi) in order to maximize detection quality.

When designing the Stinson AIS, ease of installation and configuration were two key factors we focused on throughout the process. With this in mind, we developed two sensor variants for installation in any environment: a compact shelf mount unit when cabinet space is critical and a standalone weatherproof pole mount unit when no cabinet or infrastructure is available. To further ease the simplicity of installation we have designed a flexible power supply system which makes it possible to install this device nearly anywhere.

The Stinson AIS participated in an MTO project in 2016 to test a variety of alternative Bluetooth detection devices to determine their accuracy and penetration rates. This testing was performed on Hwy 26 near Wasaga Beach and involved three vendor devices: Iteris Vantage, ISS Deep Blue, and the Stinson AIS. WSP performed the testing and evaluation which focused on the Accuracy and Penetration rate of each sensor to determine if they met industry standards. The results of the testing confirmed that the Stinson AIS met industry standards for both metrics and as such were well suited for travel time applications on roadways.

The Solution shall have a continuous monthly uptime of at minimum 99% outside of any scheduled and routine maintenance.
The Proponent shall provide remote access to the TT System Graphical User Interface (GUI) to authorized MTO users in a secured manner.
The Proponent shall collaborate with MTO to establish a site-to-site IPSec VPN tunnel between the system and MTO firewall.
The Solution shall operate and publish real-time travel time data feeds continuously (i.e. 24/7, 365 days).
The Solution shall have backup or redundancy procedures in place in order to resume normal operations upon system failure.
User access privileges shall be definable on a functional level. This shall allow for different levels and roles of users to access system features and functions.
The Solution shall support all data processing procedures required for the development of travel time information.

The Solution shall generate three (3) real-time secured data feeds: Link-based TT – TT between two adjacent BT; Route-based TT – TT between VMS and the displayed destination; and Sign-based TT message – for each destination defined for VMS.
Data feeds generated by the solution shall be sharable with partners as defined by MTO.
The GUI shall consist of a user-accessible reporting system.
The dashboard shall provide information on buffer time index (BTI) for links and routes. BTI = (TT (95th percentile) – TT (real-time)) / TT (real-time).
The Proponent shall be responsible for all maintenance of the Solution during the Term of Agreement.

The reporting system shall automatically generate the following reports on a daily, weekly, and monthly basis, and archive these reports: Ranking of routes by average speed; and Ranking of routes by average travel time per kilometre.
The dashboard shall provide information on travel time index (TTI) for links and routes. TTI = TT (real-time) / TT (free-flow).

Transnomis’ ITS Central software is currently installed as the Advanced Traffic Management System in the City of Edmonton, Region of York, Region of Durham, MTO East Region, and BC Ferries. In addition, ITS Central is the control software being used for MTO’s Queue and Stopped Vehicle Advisory System (QSVAS) on Highway 405, which is currently in the Operational Performance Test (OPT) period. ITS Central specializes in retrieving data and device status information from the field devices it’s integrated with, including the Stinson AIS Bluetooth/WiFi sensor, cellular modems, CCTV cameras, variable message signs, vehicle detectors, traffic signals, and various weather detection equipment (e.g., atmospheric sensors, wind meters, pavement sensors, etc.).
Transnomis will keep the ITS Central software up to date with the latest available software updates for the duration of the Term of Agreement.
ITS Central is able to process the raw data (MAC addresses retrieved from the sensors) into travel time information, per the MTO defined formats.

ITS Central is designed to be fully scalable, to include future geographic expansion and inclusion of additional routes. In addition, adding additional Bluetooth readers and VMS’s is a common request by our previous clients, and can be easily accommodated.

ITS Central publishes processed data to an XML file using HTTPS secured data feeds, allowing for a secured public API for future system integration and data sharing within MTO and with other jurisdictions. Permissions may be granted by the system administrator for access to the secured data feeds.

Our ITS Central software is designed to operate continuously, 24/7/365. Our ITS Central Advanced Traffic Management Systems in the City of Edmonton, Region of York, Region of Durham, MTO East Region, and BC Ferries operate continuously (24/7/365). MTO’s QSVAS is also designed for continuous operations. Our systems in Toronto, Oklahoma, and California are also running 24/7/365.

Professional third-party hosting, and triple servers are proposed to achieve 99% uptime, with an expected uptime of better than 99.99% excluding scheduled maintenance. A total of 3 servers, hosted professionally by OVH within Canada, will be utilized in this project to achieve full system triple redundancy and fail-over.

Transnomis’ ITS Central software allows for browser-based access, secured by HTTPS, password-based login, and user group permissions. User rights are managed by user groups, and users are assigned to one or more user groups. The permissions the user has is the aggregation of all of the permissions of the groups the user belongs to.
ITS Central complies with all Government of Ontario Information Technology Standards security requirements.

User access privileges are definable on a functional level. User rights are managed by user groups, and users are assigned to one or more user groups. The permissions the user has is the aggregation of all of the permissions of the groups the user belongs to.

The Proponent shall automatically infill route travel time information in the event of an origin Bluetooth reader failure. When ITS Central detects the restoration of communication to the sensor (regardless if it is an origin, destination or intermediate reader), it automatically downloads the archived data files needed from the sensor, and re-process the Bluetooth/Wi-Fi data by matching with data from other sensors, and re-computing the travel time data.

The Solution shall have the ability to identify real-time route travel time as slow traffic condition as per MTO definition. ITS Central can identify slow traffic conditions, per MTO's definition based on measured speed.
All end-to-end services of this system comply with the guidelines in the Freedom of Information and Protection of Privacy Manual published by the Government of Ontario.

The Solution shall be capable of filtering data to remove anomalies, outliers, and encrypted MAC IDs unmatched to a destination using robust statistical methods. ITS Central employs advanced algorithmic calculation of travel times between sensors by aggregating and filtering the raw travel time data eliminating aberrations and outliers. The parameters for this algorithm are configurable.

ITS Central allows MTO to define a configurable time period during which MTO will publish route travel time messages on VMS. The initial default time period shall be: • Weekdays (Monday to Friday) – 6:00am to 10:00am, 3:00pm to 8:00pm; and • Weekends (Saturday and Sunday) and statutory holidays – 9:00am to 12:00pm, 5:00pm to 9:00pm. These time periods are easily configurable.

Data shall be hosted and stored by the Proponent within Canada utilizing cloud-based solution, outside of MTO premises. For hosting, we propose the services of OVH (https://www.ovh.com/). It is one of the largest internet hosting companies in the world, with 400,000 servers, 33 data centers in 4 continents and 1.6 million customers. It is fully certified: PCI DSS, ISO/IEC 27001, 27017, 27018, 27701, 50001, SOC 1, SOC 2 and SOC 3, Cloud Security Alliance STAR certified.

Although hosting is provided by reliable third party, Transnomis Solutions is fully responsible for the availability of its software service. The Ministry will never have to deal with the hosting company. Transnomis Solutions will be the single point of contact for all issues related to services provided for this contract, including server availability issues.

The GUI shall provide a dashboard for MTO to access real-time travel time and hardware (Bluetooth reader, VMS) information. ITS Central includes a robust configurable dashboard that can display real-time travel time, and hardware/maintenance issues.
Transnomis will be responsible for obtaining and renewing the map license throughout the duration of the contracted agreement period.
Reports are preconfigured to be printer friendly and organized. It is anticipated that some further customization and feedback from MTO will be needed to ensure reports meet MTO’s needs.

Historical aggregated travel time information shall be stored and accessible to users for the duration of the Contract. Historical aggregated travel time information is stored in ITS Central's database, and will be accessible for the duration of the contract.
The dashboard display provides the information on TTI and BTI for each link and route. TTI = TT (real-time) / TT (free-flow). BTI = (TT (95th percentile) – TT (real-time)) / TT (real-time).
The reporting system includes filters to define the time periods, regions, paths, and devices.
Transnomis will setup access to the data feeds for partners who require access, as requested and authorized by MTO.

A Scheduled System Maintenance Plan will be submitted to the MTO for approval one month prior to SLA initiation. This plan will indicate all staff, staff responsibilities, resources, schedules and operating guidelines. The plan shall include a description of the processes and tasks required to carry out the Operations, Maintenance and Support of the TT Service including the procedures that address requirements of subsections 1.4.1, 1.4.2 and 1.4.3 of the SLA document. All asset locations will be included on a detailed map. Access to each asset location will be included along with a list of all potential safety hazards and traffic control requirements. In depth routine maintenance procedures will be outlined for all assets in the project inventory. Routine maintenance details and activity sequences will be in accordance with the agreed contract, previous routine maintenance experience and field information from on-site inspections.
Transnomis will provide notice and advance documentation of changes to processes and methodologies during the Term of Agreement. MTO will test and approve these changes at their discretion.
Transnomis will provide bug patches for the Central Region ITS Central as the patches are rolled out.
Transnomis will work with MTO to setup the automatic transfer of the configuration file to MTO on the last business day of every month.
ITS Central monitors the status of the AIS Stinson Bluetooth/Wifi readers in real time, and provides alert on the map interface as well as email notifications if the device requires maintenance.

During the operational and maintenance phases of the contract, Black & McDonald will be responsible for monitoring the operation of all ITS components including BT readers installed under the contract. B&M will immediately notify the MTO if any MTO-supplied material or equipment (existing or new) is discovered to be broken or faulty, affecting system performance. Field devices will be monitored by ITS Central, and notifications will be sent to B&M if a device failure is detected. In line with the Agreement, the MTO will decide on a course of action with respect to such material or equipment. When Black & McDonald Limited is notified of an occurrence, it must respond within the specified time frame. Any incidents will be documented in detail and reported to the MTO, with a summary of the root cause and corrective action taken.
The project team will refer to the SLA for operational procedures to process requests by MTO to make changes to the service configurations listed above.
ITS Central will generate daily, weekly, and monthly reports on the status of the Bluetooth Readers.

Black & McDonald (B&M) will be responsible for System Operational Support, Warranty, System Emergency Repairs, and System Routine Maintenance for the TT system. B&M will maintain fault free operation of the TT system including the hardware and software parts as well as maintaining effective working conditions according to the contract’s specifications. B&M project management team will review the restrictions outline in Appendix C3 and create a maintenance plan based on information provided. The maintenance team will carry out successful coordination with any other contractors to stay away from working in the same area by providing the advanced notice to the contract administrator or representative from general contractors. All activities will follow the requirements specified in the Service Level Agreement to ensure equipment and system performance levels are met throughout the life of the Contract.

To establish a proper project management practices and to ensure they are implemented and maintained for the 5 years-term duration of this contract and as per the SLA execution plan. Also, to introduce SLA personnel administrator and technical support staff to exchange contact information with MTO. Approach and Methodology: Once a successful completion of the Full Deployment System Acceptance is achieved as well as the Operability Period, a project maintenance meeting will begin between the MTO and the project assigned team. Questions, comments or concerns from either party will be addressed during this meeting and a detailed record of the minutes of the meeting will be retained for future reference.

A comprehensive project safety and environmental management plan will be developed and submitted to the MTO for review. The project's safety and environmental protection plan will go through site-specific safety hazards, risk mitigation measures, and environmental protection strategy, as well as a list of all hospitals and clinics in the area. All environmental work will be conducted in compliance with MTO Environmental Reference of Highway Design regulations (ERD). This plan will be reviewed by the project's management team before submitting it to the MTO for approval. The Project's Safety and Environmental Management Plan must be followed by all project personnel, including office employees and field crews. Throughout the contract, this plan will be updated and maintained.

Routine maintenance services will be scheduled in accordance to the approved Scheduled System Maintenance Plan. It will be conducted for all TT system components within the contract limits. Routine maintenance and inspection services will comply with the Equipment Specific Scheduled Maintenance Requirements outline in the SLA, manufacture recommendations and be in accordance with the ITS elements and operation and maintenance manuals. Any ITS maintenance work related to the upgrade of system components will be reviewed by approved MTO consultants and all products used for upgrades will meet the applicable project agreement requirements, in accordance with the Designated Source Material (DSM) List.

The project team will prepare a template for monthly field maintenance service. The template will be completed on a monthly basis, based on maintenance services provided and submitted to the MTO. Monthly Reports will be accompanied by each invoice.
To construct a 24-hour emergency dispatch center. Give the dispatch center and all on-call emergency workers a contact list from MTO. Make a plan for managing equipment and material.

For all call out actions, the non-routine maintenance log book will be updated every time an attendance to an electrical or ITS asset is made. Crews will keep track of when the repair was finished and when the component was fully functional.

To create a document control system to guarantee that all routine maintenance reports are completed, structured, and available to the MTO. To put in place an electronic ticketing system to track, manage, and respond to system outages and other operational concerns. To monitor and record monthly system performance, ensuring system performance metric and submitted to the MTO each month along with the monthly invoice.

The project team will implement an electronic ticketing system which logs and reports system outages or equipment operation issues. Trouble tickets will be assigned a number, priority level and technician responsible for resolution. Upon resolution, the ticket will be updated to indicate the outcome, resolution details and lessons learned.

The on-call crew will be briefed on the category of the call and sent after receiving an emergency call at either the 24/7 hour dispatch center or via the list of contacts provided to the MTO. On-call crew will have access to a service truck and some supplies from their home base.

Upon construction of the GCSS System, B&M will assume ongoing routine maintenance and emergency services for a duration of 48 months. The project team will implement an electronic ticketing system to ensure system faults are tracked and resolved within the contract timeframes.

As safety is the top priority for the GCSS System, it is critical that the GCSS System operates with high accuracy and uptime. It is our objective to design a system which promotes redundancy and fail-safe features to maintain consistent operation. System uptime will also be monitored by an external service to ensure 99.95% availability of the GCSS.

The system shall have a production environment that is exclusively used for production purposes and provides the most recent tested and accepted versions of the system modules. We will install our tested, accepted and released software on the production environment for production purposes only.
All Transnomis software has version control such that it is easy to roll back to previous versions.
ITS Central has no limit to the number of user accounts.

The system shall provide a testing environment separate from the production environment that is available for testing and demonstrating all system functionalities and upgrades without impacting the performance or functionality of the production system. This environment is intended for UDOT staff to test features and functionality, and not as a development environment for the vendor.
ITS Central is highly scalable and will have no difficulty handling many thousands of connected devices.
ITS Central can accommodate hundreds of simultaneous users.
Transnomis will review and ensure compliance to Utah DTS security policies for user access, as we have with other governmental organizations.
Transnomis will review and ensure compliance to Utah DTS policies, as we have with other governmental organizations.
ITS Central integrates with Active Directory using LDAP(S).

The system shall provide a means for administrators to view user activity in real-time. For example, an administrator will be able to view the current activities of other users logged into the system, either centrally or remotely. All user activity are logged and can be viewed in real-time by system administrators.
ITS Central provides real-time data feeds in XML and JSON formats.
ITS Central has ingested roadway information data from third-parties using XML, JSON and GeoJSON.

ITS Central allows administrators to create and manage customizable user roles (a.k.a. user groups in ITS Central) and specific permissions are customized and assigned to each user roles so that they have exactly the permissions they need to perform the roles.
ITS Central allows administrators to manage permissions of each user group, and assign users to that group.
ITS Central allows for configuration of the data retention length of time for each type of data (e.g., camera images, vehicle detector data, VMS messages, etc.) based on clients’ policies.
ITS Central has ingested data from third-party traffic data providers, including Google, Waze and TomTom.

When a data feed is not working as expected, ITS Central logs an issue into the system and generate notification (typically via email) to a configurable group of people so they can look into the issue.

The system shall monitor external interfaces and notify users of interface failures and errors. Examples of failures or errors include loss of connection or data not received by the system when expected. When a data feed is not working as expected, ITS Central logs an issue into the system and generates notification (typically via email) to a configurable group of people so they can look into the issue.

The ATMS shall manage simultaneous implementations to control permissions and priority for devices and functionality based on user hierarchy across implementations. For example, the ATMS can give priority control of local devices to a user on a local implementation. ITS Central’s user group-based permission management plus permission assigned to ITS Central data layers provide for functionality as required here.

The Video Image Capture process shall ensure that all video images provided as 'current' are no older than 5 minutes. ITS Central can capture images as frequently as necessary (for one client it captures images every 30 seconds).

The system interface monitor shall be configurable to establish frequency of notifications, thresholds that trigger notifications and users to be notified. An example of a threshold may be defining that a notification is sent to users once an external system that typically exchanges data in real-time fails to exchange data for ten minutes. ITS Central retries the data exchange for a configurable period of time – if the failure persists over that period, it will log an issue and generate notification as described.
The vendor shall provide a mechanism to capture still images from live video streams. ITS Central is capturing still images from various cameras for a number of its users.

The Video Image Capture process shall archive captured images for specific video streams for a customizable period of time. ITS Central can store camera images for a configurable period of time – configurable by individual cameras.

The ATMS Data Systems shall encrypt data at rest and in transit. ADR and ADX may be installed on a server storage with encryption. Data in transit will be encrypted if supported by the third-party devices. Encrypted VPN tunnels may be utilized as appropriate.

The system shall integrate aggregated data from the Panasonic Connected Vehicle System. This may include potential incidents, traffic speed data, and other potential data types. The API for this data is currently under development. The scope and fee for the development of this interface will be negotiated once the API is completed.

No element of the ATMS Data Systems shall interfere with or limit the operational functions of the ATMS software or any of the supporting ancillary systems. ADR and ADX will be operating as independent systems running on a separate database, and hence they will not interfere or limit the operational functions of the ATMS software.
Transnomis has designed data exchange with dozens of systems, including standards such as REST and SOAP-based API’s.

Transnomis has created data feeds within ITS Central for various devices such as cameras, VMS, vehicle detectors, travel time, weather stations, etc., and the data feeds include inventory and status information.
Transnomis has designed data exchange with dozens of systems, including third-party vendor-specific API-based methods.
Transnomis will ensure that all of the existing C2C API will be maintained.
Transnomis will work with UDOT to design the data feed for weather information that includes forecasts.

Transnomis will work with UDOT to determine the data retention periods and configure archival and/or removal of data based on the data retention policy. Data retention periods will be configurable in the ADR.
Transnomis will work with UDOT to design the ADR to store device configuration and inventory data from the ATMS and other systems.
Transnomis will work with UDOT to design the ADR data repository structure such that it will have the ability to store new and old data with large volume of data.
